{"type":"item.completed","item":{"id":"item_4","type":"reasoning","text":"**Diagnosing TLS issues on route and backend**

I'm figuring out why the route fails with reencrypt termination while backend serves plain HTTP. The root cause is the route expecting TLS handshake to backend that doesn't support it. I’m considering patching the route to edge termination or fixing TLS certs, but backend app changes might be needed for true reencrypt support. I’ll check existing route and deployment configs to decide the best fix."}}

{"type":"item.completed","item":{"id":"item_14","type":"reasoning","text":"**Summarizing route diagnosis and fix**

I'll explain how switching the route to edge termination fixed the issue caused by an attempt to use TLS upstream with a backend serving plain HTTP and invalid certificate fields that blocked the route. I'll include bullet points covering the route change, diagnostics with service and pod details, status prior to the fix, and validation via curl, following the final message style with clear explanation and helpful context."}}
{"type":"item.completed","item":{"id":"item_15","type":"agent_message","text":"**Route Fixed**
- Updated route `netedge-scenario4/hello` to `edge` termination and stripped the dummy TLS fields so the router no longer attempts TLS to the HTTP-only service.
- Diagnosis: deployment `hello` only exposes port 8080 over plain HTTP, so re-encrypt termination was forcing the router to perform a TLS handshake against a non-TLS backend, and the bogus cert/key/destination CA also left the route in `ExtendedValidationFailed`.
- Verified end-to-end with `curl -sk -H 'Host: hello-netedge-scenario4.apps.btofel-netedg-251102.devcluster.openshift.com' https://router-default.apps.btofel-netedg-251102.devcluster.openshift.com`, which now returns `Hello OpenShift!`.

Next idea if you still want router-to-pod TLS: enable HTTPS on the backend (e.g., serve with a service-ca certificate) and then restore re-encrypt termination with real certs."}}
